title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement vincenzo.coia@gmail.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to distplyr
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed).

title: Contributing to distplyr
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("vincenzocoia/distplyr", fork = TRUE). Install development dependences devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to distplyr
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: distplyr provides grammar verbs manipulating probability distributions. Operations take distribution(s) input, return distribution output, maintain mathematical correctness, can chained together.

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: Note: distplyr active development , functional, still young experience growing pains. example, currently struggles manipulating distributions aren’t continuous. limitations addressed development continues. appreciate patience welcome contributions! Please see contributing guide get started.

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: transformations can achieved using operations like +, -, *, /, ^. ’s function form: equivalent operator form: verb form useful chaining operations. ’s verbose version: concisely operators:
code: d <- dst_exp(1) shift(d, 5) #> Shifted distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Exponential distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> rate  #>    1  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 5 d + 5 #> Shifted distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Exponential distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> rate  #>    1  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 5 dst_norm(0, 1) |>    multiply(-2) |>    shift(10) #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   10    2 10 - 2 * dst_norm(0, 1) #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   10    2

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: examples transformations. Start shifting scaling: Properties update correctly: example using mix() make zero-inflated model. (NOTE: continuous distribution, distplyr struggles aspects; improvements come soon.) Make rainfall distribution: View randomly generated rainfall series:
code: d <- dst_exp(1) shifted <- shift(d, 10) scaled <- multiply(d, 5) range(d) #> [1]   0 Inf range(shifted) #> [1]  10 Inf range(scaled) #> [1]   0 Inf dry <- dst_degenerate(0) rain <- dst_gamma(5, 0.5) rainfall <- mix(dry, rain, weights = c(0.7, 0.3)) set.seed(1) x <- realize(rainfall, n = 30) plot(x, ylab = "Rainfall (mm)", xlab = "Day") lines(x)

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: apply distplyr operations distributions, package sometimes simplifies result known distribution family. example, logarithm Log-Normal distribution Normal distribution—generic transformed distribution object.

title: Manipulating Distributions
text: simplification occurs distplyr recognizes transformed combined distribution belongs known distribution family returns simpler form. ’s example simplification happens. Start Log-Normal distribution: Take logarithm, simplifies Normal: , taking maximum two distributions one strictly greater always takes bigger one. Without simplification, results generic transformed distribution object, like output maximize():
code: lognormal <- dst_lnorm(meanlog = 2, sdlog = 0.5) lognormal #> Log Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> meanlog   sdlog  #>     2.0     0.5 result <- log(lognormal) result #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>  2.0  0.5 maximize(dst_unif(0, 1), dst_unif(4, 10)) #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   4  10 maximize(dst_unif(0, 7), dst_unif(4, 10)) #> Maximum distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distributions #> $distributions[[1]] #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   0   7  #>  #> $distributions[[2]] #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   4  10  #>  #>  #> $draws #> [1] 1 1

() improve computational efficiency reduce potential rounding error propagation. keep distribution objects simpler. package include comprehensive list possible simplifications, sticks key cases thought important. see simplifications implemented, check documentation verb. accuracy simplifications ensured (1) testing simplification case expected distribution parameters, (2) verifying CDF generic (unsimplified) distribution matches CDF simplified distribution grid points.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: distplyr breathes life probability distributions providing grammar modification reshaping. works seamlessly distribution objects distionary package, builds probaverse ecosystem making representative statistical models. distplyr, can manipulate probability distributions using intuitive grammar verbs. Apply transformations, combine distributions, build complex probabilistic models simple building blocks – maintaining mathematical correctness internal consistency. name “distplyr” inspired dplyr: dplyr provides grammar manipulating data, distplyr provides grammar manipulating distributions.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: Real-world phenomena rarely follow simple textbook distributions. arise transformations, combinations, compositions simpler processes. annual maximum flow river may larger snowmelt-related flow rainfall-related flow; distribution residuals can moved regression equation obtain predictive distribution; marginal distributions can estimated averaging component distributions; rainfall total might mixture 70% dry days (zeros) `30% Gamma-distributed amounts. R excellent support standard distributions, lacks systematic way transform combine . need work distribution transformed combined random variable, ’re often left deriving formulas hand resorting simulation. distplyr fills gap providing consistent grammar verbs distribution manipulation, built top flexible distionary infrastructure. Define distributions, apply transformations, let package handle mathematical details.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: distplyr designed : Data scientists statisticians need build custom probability models go beyond standard parametric families. Researchers fields like environmental science, finance, engineering, insurance complex distributions arise combining transforming simpler processes. Modelers want express domain knowledge distribution manipulations rather constrained pre-packaged options. Students educators learning probability distributions, transformations, random variables combine. Anyone wants intuitive, programmatic way work distributions rather deriving formulas hand running simulations. work probability distributions find wishing “just shift ,” “mix together,” “see happens transform ,” distplyr .

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: install distplyr, run following code R:

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: distplyr active development , functional, still young experience growing pains. example, currently struggles manipulating distributions aren’t continuous, warnings errors provided cases. limitations addressed development continues. appreciate patience welcome contributions! Please see contributing guide get started.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: Transform distributions using functions operators: simplify Normal distributions, ’s always case. Visualize multiplication:  Apply mathematical transformations. combine distributions; case, maximum.
code: library(distionary) library(distplyr) # Create a standard Normal distribution a <- dst_norm(0, 1)  # Transform using functions shift(a, 10) #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   10    1 multiply(a, 2) #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>    0    2  # Or use operators 10 + 2 * a #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   10    2 b <- dst_beta(3, 2) d <- b * 2 d #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 2 plot(b, to = 2) plot(d, add = TRUE,  col = "red") legend(   "topright",   legend = c("Original", "Multiplied by 2"),   col = c("black", "red"),   lty = 1 ) log(dst_gamma(4, 2)) #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Gamma distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape  rate  #>     4     2 # Maximum of three sites site1 <- dst_norm(20, 2) site2 <- dst_norm(22, 3) site3 <- 2 * dst_t(3) + 19  regional_max <- maximize(site1, site2, site3)  # Plot these distributions plot(site1, lty = 2, col = "red", from = 10, to = 30) plot(site2, add = TRUE, lty = 2, col = "blue") plot(site3, add = TRUE, lty = 2, col = "green") plot(regional_max, add = TRUE) legend(   "topright",   legend = c("Maximum", "Site 1", "Site 2", "Site 3"),   col = c("black", "red", "blue", "green"),   lty = 1 )

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: See vignette("manipulating") comprehensive guide verbs, including operators (+, -, *, /), math functions (exp(), log(), sqrt()), understanding operations simplify known distributions.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: distplyr employs rigorous testing ensure mathematical computational correctness: Internal Consistency: distribution properties remain mathematically consistent . example, density integrates CDF, mean calculated density matches specified mean, quantile CDF functions proper inverses. Simplification Correctness: operations simplify known distributions (e.g., exp Normal becomes Log Normal), package verifies simplified non-simplified versions produce equivalent distributions comparing CDFs fine grid points. See vignette("manipulating") details simplifications.

what: distplyr in the Context of Other Packages
title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: R ecosystem offers several packages working probability distributions: stats Package: Provides functions standard distributions (rnorm, pnorm, etc.) lacks tools transformation composition. distr Package: Offers S4 object-oriented framework distributions transformation capabilities, steeper learning curve complex interface. distributions3 Package: Provides S3-based interface focused simplicity, suitable working standard distributions limited transformation capabilities. distributional Package: Extends distributions3 vectorization support transformations, less flexible custom operations. landscape, distplyr addresses need systematic approach distribution manipulation grammar-based framework. Built flexible distionary infrastructure, operations maintain mathematical correctness automatic simplifications can chained naturally build arbitrarily complex distributions simple building blocks. extensible framework supports adding new transformation verbs distribution families needed, making key component probaverse ecosystem.

title: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions
text: creation distplyr possible without support BGC Engineering Inc., Politecnico di Milano, European Space Agency, University British Columbia, Natural Science Engineering Research Council Canada (NSERC). authors also like thank reviewers ROpenSci review process distionary package, insightful feedback also helped development distplyr.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: Apply mathematical functions like log() exp() probability distributions. X random variable following distribution, functions return distribution transformed variable.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: x probability distribution object. ... Additional arguments passed specific methods. log(), can specify base (defaults exp(1) natural log).

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: transformed distribution object.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: S3 methods extend base R functions work distributions.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: log(x, base = exp(1)) Returns distribution log(X). base can specified (defaults natural log). error returned distribution non-positive values possible outcomes. log10(x) Returns distribution log10(X). Equivalent log(x, base = 10). exp(x) Returns distribution exp(X). sqrt(x) Returns distribution sqrt(X). Equivalent x^0.5. Requires values non-negative.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
text: power operator ^ also works distributions (see Ops.dst()). raising distribution numeric power (e.g., dst^2), uses relationship X^= exp(* log(X)), combining exponential logarithmic transformations.

title: Mathematical Transformations for Distributions — Math.dst
code: # Logarithmic transformations d <- distionary::dst_unif(1, 10) log(d)              # Natural log #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1  10  #>  log(d, base = 10)   # Log base 10 #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1  10  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.4342945 #>  log10(d)            # Also log base 10 #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1  10  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.4342945 #>  sqrt(d)             # Square root of uniform #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1  10  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.5 #>  #>   # Exponential transformation d2 <- distionary::dst_norm(0, 1) d3 <- distionary::dst_beta(5, 4) exp(d2)             # Log-normal distribution #> Log Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> meanlog   sdlog  #>       0       1  exp(d3)             # No simplification #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      5      4  #>   # These can be combined log(exp(d2))        # Returns back to normal distribution #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>    0    1  log(exp(d3))        # Still returns d3. #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      5      4  5^(log(d3, base = 5)) # Still returns d3. #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      5      4

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: Apply arithmetic operators probability distributions. operations transform distributions intuitive ways, treating similarly numeric values.

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
code: # S3 method for class 'dst' Ops(e1, e2)

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: e1 probability distribution numeric value. e2 probability distribution numeric value.

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: transformed distribution object.

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: S3 methods extend arithmetic operators work distributions.

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: d + + d Shifts distribution adding constant . Equivalent shift(). d - Shifts distribution subtracting constant . Equivalent shift(d, -). -d Flips distribution (negation). Equivalent flip(). d * * d Scales distribution multiplying constant . Equivalent multiply(). d / Scales distribution dividing constant . Equivalent multiply(d, 1/). / d Returns distribution / X (reciprocal scaling). = 1, equivalent invert(). d ^ Raises distribution power . positive distributions , computed exp(* log(d)). ^ d Returns distribution ^X. Requires positive base .

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
text: power operator ^ deserves special attention: base distribution (e.g., dst_beta(1, 1)^2), computes distribution X^using transformation exp(* log(X)). requires values distribution positive. exponent distribution (e.g., 2^dst_norm(0, 1)), computes distribution ^X using exp(X * log()). base must positive. implementations internally use Math.dst() methods log() exp().

title: Arithmetic Operations for Distributions — Ops.dst
code: d <- distionary::dst_beta(3, 2)  # Shifting and scaling d + 10          # Shift right by 10 #> Shifted distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 10 #>  d * 2           # Scale by 2 #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 2 #>  3 * d - 5       # Scale then shift #> Shifted distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 3 #>  #>  #> $shift #> [1] -5 #>   # Power operations exp(d)          # e^X: exponential of Beta #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  2^d             # 2^X: base 2 raised to Beta #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Beta distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> shape1 shape2  #>      3      2  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.6931472 #>  #>   # With positive distributions d_pos <- distionary::dst_unif(1, 2) d_pos^2         # X^2: uniform squared #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1   2  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 2 #>  #>  d_pos^0.5       # sqrt(X): square root #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1   2  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.5 #>  #>  sqrt(d_pos)     # Equivalent to d_pos^0.5 #> Exponentiated distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Logarithmic distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1   2  #>  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 0.5 #>  #>

what: distplyr: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions — distplyr-package
title: distplyr: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions — distplyr-package
text: Go beyond standard probability distributions Normal Exponential combining, shifting, maximizing, otherwise transforming distributions simple, verb-based functions. Provides easy access broader space distributions representative real-world systems river flows insurance claims. Part probaverse framework packages support advanced statistical modeling simulations intuitive workflow.

title: distplyr: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions — distplyr-package
text: distplyr package provides tools manipulating probability distributions using intuitive syntax. Key features include: Arithmetic operators: Use +, -, *, /, ^ distributions. See Ops.dst() details. Mathematical functions: Use log(), exp(), log10(), sqrt() distributions. See Math.dst() details. Transformation functions: Use shift(), multiply(), flip(), invert() transform distributions. See ?linear_transform details. Mixing distributions: Use mix() create mixture distributions.

title: distplyr: Manipulate and Combine Probability Distributions — distplyr-package
text: Maintainer: Vincenzo Coia vincenzo.coia@gmail.com [copyright holder] contributors: Amogh Joshi [contributor] Shuyi Tan [contributor] Zhipeng Zhu [contributor]

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
text: collection distributions, obtain distributions maximum (maximize()) minimum (minimize()) independent draws component distribution. Aliases maximise() minimise() also provided.

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
code: maximize(   ...,   draws = 1,   na_action_dst = c("null", "drop", "fail"),   na_action_draws = c("null", "drop", "fail") )  minimize(   ...,   draws = 1,   na_action_dst = c("null", "drop", "fail"),   na_action_draws = c("null", "drop", "fail") )

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
text: ... Distribution objects, list distributions. draws Number draws distribution considered maximum (possibly integer, never negative). Either single numeric applying distributions ..., vector matching number distributions .... na_action_dst, na_action_draws done Null distributions ... NA draws? Character vector length 1: one "fail", "null" (default), "drop". See details.

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
text: distribution class "max".

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
text: give example distribution returned, X1 X2 two random variables distributions D1 D2 respectively, maximize(D1, D2, draws = c(2, 3)) returns distribution max(X1, X1, X2, X2, X2). Distributions ... draws vector recycled length, one length 1 (via vctrs::vec_recycle_common()). na_action_dst na_action_draws specify NA action distributions draws. "NA" means either NA draws vector, Null distribution (distionary::dst_null()) distributions. Options , order precedence: "fail": Throw error presence NAs. "null": Return Null distribution presence NAs. "drop": Remove distribution-weight pairs NA value Simplifications made functions include following: distributions entirely left (right) others, removed consideration maximize() (minimize()). Finite distributions input, result also Finite distribution. distribution input multiple times, corresponding draws summed.

title: Extremum of Several Distributions — maximize
code: # One is always more extreme than the other in this case. d1 <- dst_unif(-1, 2) #> Error in dst_unif(-1, 2): could not find function "dst_unif" d2 <- dst_unif(5, 6) #> Error in dst_unif(5, 6): could not find function "dst_unif" maximize(d1, d2) # d2 #> Error: object 'd1' not found minimize(d1, d2) # d1 #> Error: object 'd1' not found  # Visualizing the maximum and minimum d3 <- dst_norm(4, 1) #> Error in dst_norm(4, 1): could not find function "dst_norm" d4 <- dst_exp(0.3) #> Error in dst_exp(0.3): could not find function "dst_exp"  dmax <- maximize(d3, d4, draws = 1:2) #> Error: object 'd3' not found dmin <- minimize(d3, d4, draws = 1:2) #> Error: object 'd3' not found  # Maximum plot(d3, col = "blue", lty = 2, from = 0, to = 14) #> Error: object 'd3' not found plot(d4, col = "red", lty = 2, add = TRUE) #> Error: object 'd4' not found plot(dmax, add = TRUE, n = 1000) #> Error: object 'dmax' not found legend(  "topright",  legend = c("Maximum", "N(4,1)", "Exp(0.3)"),  col = c("black", "blue", "red"),  lty = c(1, 2, 2) ) #> Error in (function (s, units = "user", cex = NULL, font = NULL, vfont = NULL,     ...) {    if (!is.null(vfont))         vfont <- c(typeface = pmatch(vfont[1L], Hershey$typeface),             fontindex = pmatch(vfont[2L], Hershey$fontindex))    .External.graphics(C_strWidth, as.graphicsAnnot(s), pmatch(units,         c("user", "figure", "inches")), cex, font, vfont, ...)})(dots[[1L]][[1L]], cex = dots[[2L]][[1L]], font = dots[[3L]][[1L]],     units = "user"): plot.new has not been called yet  # Minimum plot(d3, col = "blue", lty = 2, from = 0, to = 10) #> Error: object 'd3' not found plot(d4, col = "red", lty = 2, add = TRUE) #> Error: object 'd4' not found plot(dmin, add = TRUE, n = 1000) #> Error: object 'dmin' not found legend(   "topright",   legend = c("Minimum", "N(4,1)", "Exp(0.3)"),   col = c("black", "blue", "red"),   lty = c(1, 2, 2) ) #> Error in (function (s, units = "user", cex = NULL, font = NULL, vfont = NULL,     ...) {    if (!is.null(vfont))         vfont <- c(typeface = pmatch(vfont[1L], Hershey$typeface),             fontindex = pmatch(vfont[2L], Hershey$fontindex))    .External.graphics(C_strWidth, as.graphicsAnnot(s), pmatch(units,         c("user", "figure", "inches")), cex, font, vfont, ...)})(dots[[1L]][[1L]], cex = dots[[2L]][[1L]], font = dots[[3L]][[1L]],     units = "user"): plot.new has not been called yet

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: Transform distributions using location shifts, scaling, negation, reciprocals. X random variable following distribution, functions return distribution transformed variable.

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
code: flip(distribution)  invert(distribution)  multiply(distribution, constant)  shift(distribution, constant)

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: distribution probability distribution. constant numeric value shifting scaling.

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: transformed distribution.

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: transformations can applied using named functions arithmetic operators: shift(d, ) d + - Returns distribution X + multiply(d, ) d * - Returns distribution X * flip(d) -d - Returns distribution -X invert(d) 1 / d - Returns distribution 1 / X complete documentation operator usage, see Ops.dst().

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: Negation multiplication: multiply() receives negative constant, internally calls flip() result multiplying absolute value. Inversion constraint: invert() requires distribution mass zero (.e., P(X = 0) = 0). error returned condition violated.

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
text: functions apply automatic simplifications possible. example: Shifting Normal distribution returns another Normal distribution Multiplying Uniform distribution returns another Uniform distribution Flipping symmetric distribution may preserve form simplifications added future versions distplyr.

title: Linear and Reciprocal Transformations — flip
code: d_pois <- distionary::dst_pois(1.1) d_norm <- distionary::dst_norm(4, 1) d_unif <- distionary::dst_unif(0, 1)  # Shifting shift(d_pois, 1) #> Shifted distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Poisson distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> lambda  #>    1.1  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 1 #>  d_pois + 1           # Equivalent using operator #> Shifted distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Poisson distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> lambda  #>    1.1  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 1 #>   # Scaling multiply(d_unif, 2) #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   0   2  d_unif * 2           # Equivalent using operator #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   0   2   # Negation flip(d_norm) #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   -4    1  -d_norm              # Equivalent using operator #> Normal distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> mean   sd  #>   -4    1   # Inversion d_positive <- distionary::dst_unif(1, 2) invert(d_positive) #> Inverse distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1   2  #>  1 / d_positive       # Equivalent using operator #> Inverse distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Uniform distribution (continuous)  #> --Parameters-- #> min max  #>   1   2  #>   # Combine multiple operations 4 - 2 * d_pois #> Shifted distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Negated distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Poisson distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> lambda  #>    1.1  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 2 #>  #>  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 4 #>  multiply(flip(multiply(d_pois, 2)), -1) + 4  # Equivalent #> Shifted distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Scaled distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> $distribution #> Poisson distribution (discrete)  #> --Parameters-- #> lambda  #>    1.1  #>  #> $constant #> [1] 2 #>  #>  #> $shift #> [1] 4 #>

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
text: Create mixture distribution, can thought average multiple distributions (terms CDF, density, PMF, survival functions, example). Data drawn mixture distribution involves two steps: first randomly selecting distribution draw , followed random selection distribution.

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
code: mix(   ...,   weights = 1,   na_action_dst = c("null", "drop", "fail"),   na_action_w = c("null", "drop", "fail") )

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
text: ... Distribution objects, list distributions. weights Vector weights corresponding distributions; , single numeric equal weights. normalized, correspond probabilities selecting distribution. na_action_dst, na_action_w done null distributions ... NA weights? Character vector length 1: one "fail", "null" (default), "drop". See details.

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
text: mixture distribution.

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
text: Distributions ... weights vector recycled length, one length 1 (via vctrs::vec_recycle_common()). na_action_dst na_action_w specify NA action distributions weights. "NA" means either NA weights vector, Null distribution (distionary::dst_null()) distributions. Options , order precedence: "fail": Throw error presence NAs. "null": Return Null distribution presence NAs. "drop": Remove distribution-weight pairs NA value

title: Mixture Distributions — mix
code: library(distionary) a <- dst_norm(0, 1) b <- dst_norm(5, 2) m1 <- mix(a, b, weights = c(1, 4)) plot(a, col = "red", lty = 2, from = -3, to = 11) plot(b, add = TRUE, col = "blue", lty = 2) plot(m1, add = TRUE) legend(   "topright",    legend = c("Mixture", "N(0,1)", "N(5,2)"),    col = c("black", "red", "blue"),    lty = c(1, 2, 2) )

title: distplyr 0.1.5
text: Updates package infrastructure process migrating new GitHub Organization.

title: distplyr 0.1.4
text: Fix graft distributions can evaluate NA.

title: distplyr 0.1.3
text: Default evaluation methods, base distributional forms, moved new package, distionary. distplyr focusses manipulation verbs . Math method now applies finite distributions. Ops methods now available arithmetic operations (+, -, *, /) single distribution, along verbs shift(), multiply(), invert(), flip(). graft_left() graft_right() fully functional, slice_left() slice_right() now also available.

title: distplyr 0.1.2
text: tibble package installed, distplyr now output tibbles wherever data frames previously output.

title: distplyr 0.1.2
text: now, get_ prefix still holds distributional representations, like get_cdf(). Make distribution object distribution() instead dst(), checked is_distribution().

title: distplyr 0.1.1
text: patch fixes problems previous release, well offering step towards bigger expansion. Changed random number generation randfn, functional representation, realise() realize() functions. Changed probfn representation specific: pmf density Added enframe suite functions. Implement beginnings able specify distribution, set_ suite functions, making empty distribution dst(). Additionally, ’s internal rearrangement, get functions call eval functions, vice versa.

title: distplyr 0.1.0
text: first version distplyr now available! functionality rather limited moment, still useful, especially capability handle discrete component distribution. main features: Base distributions include step distributions, Gaussian, Uniform, generalized Pareto. Operations include grafting (right) mixing Distribution properties included moment-related quantities, extreme value index. Distribution representations mostly comprehensive, perhaps missing mean excess function moment generating function. Take look “Vision” vignette get sense package headed.
